question: Then I got him again at the Pierre at four o'clock.
answer: Be a dear, Mae. I don't happen to have Mr. Vallone.

question: You know what I want for him.
answer: But I have only six Barbra's left. You know how difficult she is to work with.

question: How the hell did that girl get in there? Jesus, they certainly don't give you very good protection, do they? Look at you here. Who the hell is watching you? Any one of these freaks could just walk right up to you and do whatever he wants. Just a minute. This is crazy. Okay! Stand back! Didn't you hear me?!? Come on, people, have a heart. Stand back! Go ahead, Jerry.
answer: Thanks. Thanks very much.

question: I hate to bother you like this, Jerry, but could I speak to you for a minute.
answer: I'd like to but ...

question: I know you're a busy man. I promise not to take very long, really. But I need your advice. You don't have a handkerchief, do you? Jesus, these people will kill you for a cufflink. Thanks. If you have to be somewhere, I don't mind talking as we drive. You can drop me off anywhere.
answer: Sorry, but I've got a strict rule never to ...

question: I put myself on the line for you, Jerry. Thanks, Jerry. I'm grateful for this chance to talk to you ... I hope I'm not boring you.
answer: I'll let you know.

question: Really? Fine. I'm Rupert Pupkin, Jerry. I know that the name itself doesn't mean very much to you but it means an awful lot to me, believe me. Maybe you've seen me
answer: Well ...

question: Well, up to now, I've been biding my time, developing my act slowly and carefully so that when my big break finally comes, I'm ready -- like you were that night Paar got sick and you sat in for him. I was there that night, in the theater. That was the most important night of my life, until tonight, of course.
answer: No thanks. I don't smoke.

question: Me neither. I just carry them as a courtesy. How about a cough drop?
answer: No thanks. I don't cough.

question: I try not to but sometimes, you know ... Am I making any sense?
answer: Go on.

question: Well, that night you did Paar, I walked out of the theater like I was in a dream. All of a sudden, I knew what I wanted. I started catching your guest appearances on Sullivan and taping them and, when you got your own show, it got to be a kind of regular thing. I studied how you built to your one-liners, nice and relaxed like you were chatting, and how you delivered Jerry?
answer: Look ... er ... what was the name?

question: I'm Rupert, Jerry.
answer: Look, Rupert. I know what you're saying. But things don't work that way. You can't just walk onto a network show without any experience. You've got to start at the bottom ...

question: But that's where I am!
answer: You've got to work your way up, learn your trade in front of live audiences, start playing the little clubs.

question: But that can take years, Jerry! Look at me. I'm already 31 years old! People my age are way ahead of me. I've got some catching up to do and I need your help. What do you say, Jerry? All I'm asking you to do is listen to my act. That's all. Is that asking too much?
answer: I get calls from agents every day. All they want ...

question: I tried getting an agent. I did, Jerry.
answer: Look, why don't you call my office.

question: Could I?!? Oh, I knew you'd say that, Jerry. You don't know how many times I've had this conversation in my head. And this is the way it always turns out. That's why I had to sort of invite myself into the car tonight. I know it's kind of presumptuous and I really appreciate the time you've given me. But breaks like this don't just happen. You have to make your own breaks.
answer: Nice meeting you, Rupert. I hope it all works out for you.

question: Thanks, Jerry. I don't know how to repay you. I'm a little short on cash this evening, but, if you don't mind some good, hearty food, I'd be honored to take you to dinner.
answer: Thanks, but some people are waiting for me.

question: Oh, I understand. Well, then, maybe I could repay you with a joke. Wait a minute. How's this? The first night you do your show from the coast, you open this way. "Good evening, ladies and gentlemen, it's great to be back here in
answer: Not bad. Maybe.

question: Consider it a gift. Hey, Jerry! How about lunch? My treat!
answer: Call my office.

question: You look tired, Jerry.
answer: It shows, does it? It's all these problems with the show. That and the custody suit.

question: I was sorry to read about that, Jerry. Charlene never should have gotten the kids. If there's anything I can do.
answer: I appreciate it, Rube. Just talking about it a little with you helps.

question: Hasn't Eddie already done you?
answer: Never mind. You were saying ...

question: Well, I've been giving a lot of thought to your situation, Jerry, ever since I saw you starting to lose ground in the ratings. And I think I know what the problem is. Too many of the same faces.
answer: Yeah?

question: Sure, people are getting tired of these people who live off game shows and talk shows and can't really do anything. They've seen 'em and heard 'em till they can't stand it anymore.
answer: You know, maybe you're right, Rube.

question: I'm sure I am. When a show runs out of surprises, it loses its audience. What's your name, dear? To Dolores, who sensed greatness. Rupert Pupkin. You see what I mean? What you need on the show is some unknown quantity, some brilliant talent making his television debut. Imagine the suspense. Who is this young guy? How will he do with the eyes of all America on him? Something like that has got to help.
answer: And that's where you come in.

question: Why not? Believe me, Jerry, I'd give you the credit you deserve and I'll stick with you. Anytime you need me, I'll be there, doing a few minutes at Guild scale.
answer: I'd be grateful, Rube. I really would.

question: Oh, Jerry, you sneaky ...
answer: Looks good, Eddie.

question: Miss! A beer please, Miss. Something imported.
answer: Heineken's alright?

question: Fine. How have you been, Rita?
answer: You're not Rupert Pupkin! How the hell did you find me?

question: Sally Gardner, I met her after a matinee. Aren't you glad to see me?
answer: Sure, sure. How is old Sally?

question: The same, I guess. You know, two kids, a nice husband, living in Clifton.
answer: It figures.

question: A lot of the kids in our class have moved back.
answer: What are you doing here?

question: I just thought I'd say hello. Here, I brought you a little something.
answer: Oh, yeah, Mr. Romance.

question: Don't forget to put in an aspirin. It lasts longer.
answer: Nothing's gonna keep it alive in this place.

question: How have you been, dear, sweet Rita?
answer: I don't have an aspirin.

question: Maybe a Rolaids would work.
answer: Well, what are you up to these days, Rupert?

question: Didn't you know you'd see me again?
answer: You still going to the movies?

question: You're looking as beautiful as ever.
answer: Oh, yeah. I was a real knockout.

question: I thought so.
answer: Well, here I am. Local cheerleader makes good.

question: I voted for you for Most Beautiful.
answer: Yeah?

question: I didn't have the nerve to tell you then, but I guess it's alright now.
answer: Well, nothing terrible's gonna happen, if that's what you mean. Well, how are things with you, Rupert?

question: Great! Everything's starting to break.
answer: Is that right?

question: Yeah. As a matter of fact, that's why I'm here. I've known about this place for a long time. I just didn't want to make my move until I had something to offer you. Everything's a question of timing. What's the matter?
answer: Jesus Christ, Rupert Pupkin!

question: The two of us are often confused. He's the one with the famous father. You like this place?
answer: Why, you got something better?

question: Maybe.
answer: What?

question: What are you doing tonight?
answer: Tonight?

question: What's so funny?
answer: You call me up all junior and senior year. Night after night after night, right? And every time I'm wondering 'when is this guy going to stop talking and ask me out?' Well, now I know the answer. August twelfth, nineteen seventy-six. It only took you ten, eleven years to work up to it.

question: If I had asked you out? Would you have gone?
answer: Oh, no.

question: Why not?
answer: Because I thought you were a jerk!

question: Excuse me a minute, honey.
answer: I'm not honey! I'm Rupert. Miss! Miss! I'm in the mood to celebrate tonight. Why don't we go to this nice restaurant I know, talk over and times, get to know each other all over again.

question: And then?
answer: Well, tomorrow night I thought we'd go out again, talk some more, get to know each other even better.

question: How much?
answer: How much what?

question: How much do we have to get to know each other?
answer: I don't understand.

question: How much do we have to get to know each other before we start talking about that job?
answer: I'm not talking about any job.

question: Then what's this big offer you were talking about?
answer: You'll see. Right now I'm asking you for a date. How about it?

question: I'm sorry, Rupert. But I'm busy.
answer: Busy?

question: Yeah. Busy.
answer: But this is the biggest night of my life.

question: Miss! Miss! Is that your date?
answer: None of your business.

question: What do you want to go out with him for?
answer: He's a good friend of mine.

question: Tell him you're busy.
answer: What's so important about tonight?

question: Everything! You don't understand.
answer: No. I don't. It's been really nice seeing you, Rupert. Thanks for dropping in. But I've got some work to do.

question: Miss! Listen to me for a second.
answer: I have work to do, Rupert.

question: Just listen. I'm at the start of something really big. I don't want to talk about it here but it's going to happen soon and it's going to be great -- for both of us.
answer: No kidding?

question: He was making trouble one minute and the next he was on the floor. Okay, Tarzan. Where do we eat tonight? Another one, Chan.
answer: Chopsticks, please.

question: So all this time you've been thinking about me, huh?
answer: That's right, Rita.

question: What kinds of things were you thinking? Oh, ho! Those kinds of things! Shame on you, Rupert.
answer: Rita, I assure you there was ...

question: Rupert Pupkin is an unclean person!
answer: Come on, Rita. People will hear.

question: Rupert Pupkin is an unclean person. Oh, come on, Rupert. Relax. Have a little fun.
answer: This is a very important evening to me, Rita.

question: Did you know your nose wiggled when you talked?
answer: It does?

question: Yeah. Just the tip. Like a rabbit. Hey, are we gonna eat or what? I'm starving. It always looks like they put worms in this stuff.
answer: Just taste.

question: Well, I guess it won't kill me.
answer: This is supposed to be the finest Cantonese cuisine in the city.

question: Yeah? Then what happened to the tablecloths? Oh, don't worry about it. This is
answer: I used to see you at the Garden every year.

question: Oh, the Follies. That was the right name for 'em. How did you know which one was me? We all looked like chickens. What I mean is, we all looked like the same chicken. I thought it was gonna be Rita Keane in the Ice Follies and I wind up looking like Henny Penny.
answer: You just didn't get the breaks.

question: Breaks, bullshit! My parents didn't have the money for the right coach. But what difference does it make? I remember once we were down in Atlanta and the ice machine broke down. We did three hours of slush. Everyone was falling on their faces and hopping up with their arms open for a bow like the whole thing was planned. And the people ate it up.
answer: I liked the show.

question: Yeah? The Follies? You really must have been carrying the torch. What did you think when I got married? You knew I got married?
answer: I knew it wouldn't last.

question: You think I should have married you, instead, huh?
answer: Peter Drysdale! Really, Rita!

question: If he'd only been hit by a train. He was worth a helluva lot more dead than alive, I can tell you that.
answer: Are you seeing anyone?

question: What do you mean?
answer: I want to know about the competition, that's all.

question: Well, tomorrow night, I've got a date with Joe Namath -- you know Joe. And Thursday --- let's see --
answer: I'm serious, Rita.

question: I'm serious, Rita. Sure I see people. I'm not a nun, Rupert. I see a lot of people.
answer: Anyone special?

question: You mean am I "going steady"? Rupert, I'm thirty-one years old!
answer: What about that guy tonight?

question: Him?
answer: Why him?

question: What am I supposed to do, huh? Sit home watching TV? He's just some guy. He's got his own aluminum siding business. He comes into the city sometimes, that's all.
answer: You don't go out with him for his money?!?

question: Oh, horrors! Look, Rupert, what do you think they pay me in that dump? Ninety-five bucks. And you don't get the world's greatest tippers in there either. Somebody has to take care of me.
answer: That's what I want to talk to you about, Rita. Who's your favorite movie star?

question: You are, Rupert. Especially your nose.
answer: Just tell me.

question: Is this some kind of game? Are you going to tell me something about my character?
answer: You'll see. Give me his name.

question: I can't think of anybody.
answer: You've got to have one, Rita. Everybody does.

question: Okay. Okay. Let's see. Marilyn Monroe. Oh, Rupert! Are we going to exchange That's her name.
answer: Her name! She signed this herself, especially for me. She wasn't a great actress but she had a real gift for comedy. She died tragically, you know, alone, like so many of the world's most beautiful women. I'm going to see that doesn't happen to you, Rita.

question: Who's this one?
answer: Burt Reynolds.

question: Oh yeah, the guy with no clothes. Who's this?
answer: Mel Brooks.

question: And this?
answer: Carol Burnett.

question: No kidding. How about this?
answer: Glenda Jackson.

question: Never heard of her.
answer: And that's Woody Allen and there's

question: You don't really know any of these people?
answer: Take a look at this.

question: I can't make it out.
answer: Try.

question: This is really weird handwriting!
answer: Rooooper ....

question: Redford!
answer: That's Robert Redford.

question: It is?
answer: No! It's ... it's Rupert Pupkin Don't lose it. It's going to be worth something in a couple of weeks. That's what I've been trying to tell you. Things are really breaking for me. I'm ticketed for stardom. Only a couple of hours ago, I was talking to Jerry Langford, the Jerry Langford. Stop it, Rita! We were talking about my doing my act on his show.

question: Your act?
answer: Get that guy you knew from Clifton out of your head right now. You're looking at Rupert Pupkin, Rita. Rupert Pupkin, the new King of Comedy.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Why not me, Rita? A guy can always get what he wants if he's willing to pay the price. All it takes is a little talent and sacrifice and the right break. If you've got a friend in the right place, that's all it takes. And that's exactly what I have going for me right now. After all, crazier things have happened. You just don't realize what a shot on the Langford Show can mean. That's coast to coast, national TV, a bigger audience than the greatest comedians used to play to in a lifetime. A shot like that means a free ticket on the comedy circuit -- Flip Wilson one week, Cosby the next, then Sonny and Cher or Carol Burnett. And you've always got those other talk shows to fall back on -- Carson, Griffin. And all that leads straight in one direction, Rita -- Hollywood! That's when we really start

question: It sounds wonderful, Rupert, and I really hope you get what you want. But it's getting late and I'm a working girl. You know what I mean?
answer: You going to spend the rest of your life in that place? Is that what you really want, talking about nothing with nothings? I thought you wanted something a little better than that and that's what I'm offering. Every King needs a Queen, Rita. I want you to be mine. What do you say?

question: Me? Nobody knows I'm here. You didn't tell anybody, did you?
answer: No.

question: What the hell's going on? Hello? Who is this? Where are you? You know who that was -- the bar. I have to go back to work.
answer: How did they know you were here?

question: I guess I must have told them. They need someone right away.
answer: You don't even care, do you?

question: Oh, no. I do. Really!
answer: It's not the bar, Rita. Don't tell me it's the bar.

question: Don't be angry. It has nothing to do with you. I had a nice dinner, really. It was great seeing you again. Come on. Let's see a smile.
answer: Why don't we finish the evening up at the bar together? End the evening where it began?

question: After what happened there?
answer: Well, I could at least drop you off!

question: That's okay. Really. I can manage. Why don't you just go to a movie or something? Don't let me spoil your evening.
answer: But that wouldn't be right.

question: Look, Rupert. It's been a lot of fun, really. I'll see you sometime, huh?
answer: But Rita!

question: Come on, Rupert. I'm in a hurry.
answer: Welcome to the pleasure dome.

question: You don't kid around, do you?
answer: I do alright. What's your libation?

question: Huh?
answer: Your potion. Your drink.

question: Bourbon and soda. Make it light.
answer: You from the South?

question: Me?
answer: That's what Southern people drink. Lots of bourbon.

question: What do people from Jersey drink?
answer: I make it a point to study things like that. It's important to know people's backgrounds, their tastes, their culture. It gives you a little head start. I'm Chet. Whom do I have the pleasure of serving?

question: I'm Mary.
answer: Pleased to meat you, Mary. To our evening.

question: Leisure is America's fastest growing industry. Did you know that? Think about it. Short work weeks, more vacation. People need something to do with all that time and that's where I come in. Leisure Villages, Inc. We buy land an hour or so outside your metropolitan centers. We set up the bungalows, dig some lakes, lay out a golf course, you know, fix the whole place up so it's usable. Then young, personable guys like me show the people around. It the guy seems tight, we point out the investment factor. If he's a swinger, well, the bungalows are very private. If he's a sports nut, we talk up skiing and fishing and tennis. What's your work, Mary?
answer: Me. I fly for National.

question: No kidding?
answer: What's that smell?

question: Did you know that you have remarkable hair?
answer: Yeah? You know what? I feel like going to a movie.

question: Now?
answer: Sure. Why not? It's only twenty of ten. We can make a ten o'clock show.

question: Why don't we make our own movie?
answer: No. I don't think so.

question: Don't be so uptight. Give it a chance.
answer: I want to go to the movies, that's all.

question: We can go to the movies later.
answer: Let's stop playing games, okay. I'm not a kid.

question: You have something against pleasure?
answer: I'm just not interested in being tonight's ritual sacrifice, okay?

question: Shall I freshen up your drink? What exactly did you think we were going to do up here? Look, if you've got sexual problems let's talk about them. It helps clear the air.
answer: There's nothing wrong with me.

question: Then it's me?
answer: I don't even know you.

question: Then find out. Sex is a great way of breaking down barriers.
answer: I don't think so.

question: I'm sure this could lead to something beautiful. Passive resistance, huh?
answer: Let's just write this thing off as a big mistake. What do you say?

question: What's wrong with me?
answer: Nothing. I just want to go home.

question: I can see I'm not turning you on.
answer: You noticed that, huh?

question: Come on. What's wrong with me?
answer: You really want to know?

question: Yeah.
answer: How can I put it? Well, it's like you've got your fly open and your tongue hanging out.

question: I'm really a very sensitive person.
answer: Come on. Get offa me.

question: Sometimes I write poetry.
answer: No!

question: So you wanna play hard to get, huh?
answer: Come on. Let's talk this over.

question: I admire you very much. I respect you, Mary.
answer: You're hurting me.

question: I'm only doing what you want.
answer: Oh, please.

question: Rita!
answer: What do you want?

question: Don't be angry with me. I was worried about you, that's all.
answer: Just go home and leave me alone.

question: Here. You'll need this. It's getting chilly.
answer: I'm so bad. I'm such a dummy.

question: Don't say that, Rita. Everyone does crazy things.
answer: Not all the time.

question: I'll get us a cab.
answer: Well, I guess you're entitled to come up for coffee.

question: That's okay, Rita. You're tired and I know I'm not always the easiest guy to be with.
answer: What do you want, Rupert?

question: You don't understand anything, do you? I love you, Rita. I want to change your life ... if you'll only give me a chance. Look, what if I arranged it so you could meet Jerry? You'd have to believe me if you heard it from him.
answer: There's no ...

question: I'll arrange that, Rita. We'll all go out to dinner some night or maybe out to his place, on a weekend. You'll see. The trouble with you is you've got no faith. Now go to bed and get a good rest and I'll see you in a couple of days. Now run along in. Go on.
answer: Yes.

question: I need somebody to sign. You can sign anything you want -- Cary Grant, Art Carney, I don't care. Would you mind very much if I used your phone? It's local.
answer: Don't be, long. Dial nine.

question: May I speak to Jerry Langford, please? Thanks ... Jerry Langford, please. Rupert Pupkin ... Jerry knows. I'm calling at his request ... I see. That's alright. I'll call him again.
answer: That's not Jerry Langford, the ...

question: Jerry Langford, please ... May I speak to Jerry Langford, please ... Rupert Pupkin, I called earlier ... I see. How long do you expect that'll last? Oh, fine. I'm at CH 4-1482 ... I'll be here for another half hour, forty- five minutes. Please be sure he gets my message. Thanks.
answer: Yes sir?

question: Mr. Langford, please.
answer: Your name?

question: As a matter of fact, yesterday I went to the outdoor market near where I live and I bought twenty grapefruit. The grocer looked at me and said, "What are you gonna do with all those?" So I bent over and told him "I'm gonna take 'em back to Florida and set 'em free!"
answer: I'm sorry, Mr. Pupkin, but Mr. Langford's secretary has no record of any appointment.

question: Pardon me?
answer: Mr. Langford's secretary has no record of any appointment.

question: Well, technically speaking, I don't actually have an appointment. Jerry asked me to call him today and when I couldn't get through, I thought ...
answer: I see. He says Mr. Langford asked him to call. Mr. Langford's secretary wants to know what this is in reference to. Would you mind talking to her yourself?

question: Hello? ... Jerry and I discussed my being on the show last night and he told me to call ... No. I don't mind. I'm supposed to wait. Who was that gentleman? (PUPKIN
answer: Mr. Gangemi.

question: Oh, I see. Mr. Gangemi.
answer: He takes care of our air conditioning.

question: Uh ... Mr. Pupkin?
answer: Yes?

question: I'm Cathy Long.
answer: I'm Mr. Pupkin.

question: Can I help you?
answer: I'm sorry, but you are?

question: I'm Bert Thomas' assistant.
answer: Bert Thomas?

question: He's our executive producer.
answer: Oh, yes. I'm sure he is. But, you see, I've already talked directly with Jerry about my being on the show and he told me to get in touch with him. I'm just here to follow up on that.

question: What do you do, Mr. Pupkin?
answer: Stand-up comedy.

question: Fine. Where are you working?
answer: Well, right now I'm developing new material.

question: I see. Well, as soon as you start performing again, let us know where you are and I'll send my assistant down to check you out.
answer: Sure. Sure. But that's not necessary, Miss Long. Jerry and I already went over all this.

question: Does Jerry know your work?
answer: Yes. I don't think he does.

question: You don't happen to have a tape or a demo that we might listen to?
answer: Oh, sure. I've got lots of tapes. That's no problem.

question: Good. Why don't you just send one to us and I assure you we'll listen to it promptly.
answer: Great. I'll do that. I can see that'd be a lot easier for Jerry. Thanks a lot, Miss Long.

question: Don't mention it, Mr. Pupkin. Now, if you'd excuse me ...
answer: Sure. Sure. Thanks again. Thanks.

question: Sure. Sure. Thanks again. Thanks.
answer: I've got to speak to you for a minute. I'm Marsha.

question: Yeah. I know.
answer: Look. Did Jerry say anything about me last night?

question: I'm really in a hurry, Marsha ...
answer: Was he angry? ... In the car last night, I saw you. Did he talk about me?

question: I thought that was you. That was some stunt.
answer: What did he say?

question: We didn't talk about you.
answer: You know Jerry?

question: Yeah.
answer: Give him this for me.

question: Why don't you ...
answer: Because I can't! Please. I need your help. You'll be my friend forever. Come on. I'll buy you something. What do you want?

question: I don't want this.
answer: Take it. I can get all I want.

question: Okay. I'll try.
answer: Don't try. Do it. Remember. We just made a deal. And don't open it. It's private.

question: Okay. Okay.
answer: How soon can you get it to him?

question: I don't know. Couple a days.
answer: You'd better. gave him. There are wads of tens, twenties and fifties with a sprinkling of fives and ones.

question: Testing. Testing. Testing. First, Miss Long. Thanks very much for your help at the office and for passing this along to Jerry. I appreciate it more than you know. Now, Jerry. Before I begin, I just want to thank you for listening to this material and for the opportunity that you've given me. You know, lots of people think that guys like you, you know, people who have made it, lose their feeling for struggling ... the comedy find of the year making his television debut, Rupert Pupkin, the King of Comedy! Now you come on, Jerry, and do your monologue. Then, when the time comes, this is how I see you introducing me. You'll say something like this. "Ladies and Gentlemen we're going to do something a little bit different tonight. It isn't often that you can call someone a sure thing in the entertainment business. After all, the verdict is always in your hands. But I think after you've met my next guest, that you'll agree with me that he's destined for greatness. So, now, will you please give your warmest welcome to the newest King of Comedy, Rupert Pupkin!!!" Will somebody tell that lovely lady that the applause sign is off. That's a possible introduction, Jerry. Now let's move on to my act.
answer: Yes?

question: I didn't want to take any chances with this ... uh ... Miss Long, so I ... uh ... thought I'd just bring it here myself.
answer: We talked about this this morning, did we, Mr. ... ?

question: Pupkin. Rupert Pupkin.
answer: Oh, yes. It's been some day. Well, I certainly appreciate your bringing this over, Mr. Pupkin, and we'll listen to it as soon as possible.

question: Fine. Er ... you don't have any idea how soon that might be?
answer: Well, you can try checking with us tomorrow. We might know something by then. Otherwise, it'll have to be Monday.

question: What if I just sort of waited around here today, just in case? I'll stay out of the way.
answer: You'd just be wasting your time, Mr. Pupkin. We won't know anything until tomorrow at the earliest.

question: Oh, I wouldn't consider it a waste of
answer: Look, why don't you try us tomorrow. Okay?

question: Tomorrow? ... Right. I'll do that. Thanks a lot, Miss Long. And thank Jerry.
answer: Dynamite! This is dynamite!

question: You think so, Jerry?
answer: Look, I've been at this for fifteen years, Rupert, and I haven't come up with anything like this -- not me, not any of my writers.

question: Well, I'm glad you like it, Jerry.
answer: Tell me something, Rube. How do you do it? I'm not asking to use the material myself. I just want to know how you how you do it.

question: Well, I don't know if I can explain it, really.
answer: Come on. Try, Rube.

question: Well, it just sort of comes. I think about my life, see, mainly about the worst parts, all the awful things, and I just try to see them in a funny light. That's all.
answer: Is that what you do? The worst parts, and then you look at them in a funny light? Is that what you do?

question: More or less. It's hard to describe how its happens.
answer: But that's just it, Rube. It doesn't happen for me. Why do you think the show is in so much trouble? By the time I've done my monologue, everyone has switched to Carson. Maybe if you did a little writing ... ?

question: Sure, Jerry, I'd do anything I could to help out.
answer: You would? Great. Why don't you come out to my place this weekend and we'll hash it out. I'm having a few of my friends but we should be able to get a little work in.

question: Would you mind if I brought someone?
answer: A girl, Rube?

question: A very special girl, Jerry.
answer: I'd love to meet her. That's alright, thanks.

question: Yes, sir? Oh, hi.
answer: Hi. How are you?

question: Not bad.
answer: I'm fine.

question: Can I help you?
answer: I'd like to see Jerry, please.

question: You are ... ?
answer: Mr. Pupkin.

question: Just a minute. Mr. Pupkin is here ... That's right ... She'll be with you in a minute.
answer: Who?

question: Miss Long.
answer: But I wanted to see Jerry.

question: Mr. Langford's not in. Miss Long will take care of you.
answer: Alright.

question: Alright.
answer: Mr. Pupkin?

question: How are you today?
answer: Fine, Mr. Pupkin. Thank you for your tape. We listened to it with great interest. And, frankly, Mr. Pupkin, we saw a lot of good things in what you're doing. We feel you have good potential. Very good potential.

question: Thanks.
answer: That's why I'll be honest with you, Mr. Pupkin ...

question: Yes?
answer: We just don't think you're ready yet.

question: Not ready?
answer: Well, we just don't feel right now that you're right for Jerry.

question: Right for Jerry. Sure.
answer: Some of the material ... some of the one-liners, for instance ...

question: Yes?
answer: ... were not very strong.

question: You didn't care for some of the jokes, is that it?
answer: That"s right.

question: Good. Good. I can take care of that right way. Thanks. Just tell me the ones you think should go. That would be a big help. This is great. Which ones?
answer: Well, it's not just that, Mr. Pupkin. You see, Jerry likes to panel his guests, you know, chat with them afterwards.

question: Sure. Sure.
answer: And frankly, we just don't feel you've got very much to talk about right now.

question: But I've got my whole life to talk about!
answer: Which is interesting to you, I'm sure and to your wife ... and to a few friends. But we feel that you should keep developing your act. Test it in some live situations. There are a number of clubs in the city you can

question: May I ask you a question, Miss Long?
answer: Of course.

question: Are you speaking for Jerry?
answer: Let's put it this way, Mr. Pupkin. Mr. Langford has complete faith in our judgment.

question: I'm sorry to have to say this, Miss Long, and I certainly don't want you to take it personally, but I have to tell you that I don't ... I don't have faith in your judgment.
answer: Well, I'm sorry you feel that way, Mr. Pupkin. But I'm afraid there's nothing that can be done about that.

question: No ... No ... I'm afraid I'll have to disagree with you again.
answer: That's your privilege, Mr. Pupkin. Now, if you'll excuse me, please, I have some things to do. I'm sorry the news isn't better.

question: Miss Long? When are you expecting Jerry in?
answer: He won't be in until very late this afternoon.

question: That's fine. Thank you.
answer: Is there anyone else you would like to see?

question: That's alright. I'm happy just waiting.
answer: Well, would you mind waiting outside, please, Mr. Pupkin? This is a reception area, not a waiting room.

question: I understand.
answer: Now I think you understand that we have certain rules here that are essential to the smooth functioning of our operation.

question: Sure. Sure.
answer: And that without these rules, we really wouldn't be able to function at our best. You follow my point? Now one of these rules is that only authorized personnel and those having official business with our organization are permitted on our premises. And that's why I'm asking you, Mr. Pupkin, to cooperate with us.

question: You want me to leave the building.
answer: That's right. It's nothing personal, Mr. Pupkin. Just doing my job. Have a pleasant day.

question: Well, did you give it to him?
answer: Huh?

question: Did you get my letter to him?
answer: He's not in there.

question: Look, if you don't want to give it him, okay. I'll get somebody else. But don't try to con me.
answer: I told you I'd try and I will. I'm going to wait for him right here.

question: Give me the envelope, huh?
answer: Sure, but ...

question: I saw him go in myself!
answer: Who?

question: Jerry!
answer: But they said he wasn't in.

question: Just give me the envelope.
answer: When did he go in?

question: Ten minutes ago! That's when.
answer: You sure?

question: Look, I saw him my ...
answer: And he hasn't come out?

question: I've been standing right here. Now how about it? I'm staying right here!
answer: Tell Jerry Langford I'm here, please.

question: Tell Jerry Langford I'm here, please.
answer: I'm sorry, sir. Mr. Langford's not in.

question: I happen to know he is. So would you
answer: I'm sorry. He's not in.

question: You're putting your job on the line, lady. Jerry! Jerry! You're going the have a hell of a lot of explaining to do! Jerry!
answer: You had your warning, Mr. Krupkin.

question: Jerry! Help me. Jerry! Jerry!
answer: If we see your face again, Mr. Pupkin, we'll call the police.

question: Start looking for a new job!
answer: Well?

question: Huh?
answer: Does he have it?

question: Don't worry. I'll get it to him.
answer: Yeah? When?

question: This weekend. He asked me to go out there, to his house.
answer: What are we going to do?

question: Look, I told you, I've got some work to discuss with him. That's all.
answer: But what about me?

question: You're with me.
answer: That's fine, but while you two are talking, what am I going to do?

question: You can chat with the other guests.
answer: I'm sure they'll be thrilled hearing about the wonderful world of draft beer. Let's tell 'em I'm a model, okay?

question: What?
answer: If they ask what I do, let's just say I model. You don't mind pretending just a little, do you?

question: If it make you feel better.
answer: This is a gas! Too bad nobody'll believe it. After you guys are done working, what happens? Are we going out someplace, or what?

question: I'm sure Jerry has something arranged.
answer: What do these people do for fun? Do they party or do freaky things or just get drunk or ... I mean, What do they do?

question: I guess they just sit around and talk and enjoy each other's company, like anybody else.
answer: Talk?!? What can you talk about for three or four hours?!

question: What do you mean? They've got plenty to talk about. They do things. All kinds of interesting things happen to them and then they talk about them. What do you think Jerry's show is all about?
answer: Yeah, a cocktail party with no drinks. That's what all those shows are. At least they help you get to sleep. Boy, this is going to be some great weekend. I thought we were gonna have some fun.

question: You sure?
answer: Look, friend, I wouldn't want to tell you how many times I made this trip. That'll be three seventy-five.

question: Keep it.
answer: Thanks. If you need a ride back, just ask the guy for Wayne. That's me.

question: You must be Jonno. I'm Rupert Pupkin and this is Rita Keane. Mr. Langford's expecting us.
answer: Mr. Langford asked you to come?

question: That's right. Would you mind taking those up? Jerry and I have some work that may oblige me to stay overnight.
answer: But Mr. Langford's not here.

question: Out playing golf, right?
answer: That's right.

question: Maybe he'll finally break a hundred.
answer: Maybe it's better if you came back ...

question: How do you like it?
answer: I could live here.

question: It's the only way to live.
answer: How come he isn't here?

question: You heard the guy. He's out playing golf.
answer: Didn't you tell him when we'd get here?

question: We didn't have time to iron out the details. Now just relax. We're the first guests, that's all.
answer: That Jonno character hadn't even heard of us!

question: It probably slipped Jerry's mind. He has better things to think about than what he tells his houseboy.
answer: It's just not time way I expected it, that's all. What do we do now?

question: These are Jerry's parents. His father runs the Post office in Wolverine -- that's in North Dakota. This one was in Newsweek. He started giving these puppet shows when he was still in grade school. And this is from his quiz show in St. Louis. Can you believe it?
answer: Sure I can.

question: That was the name of the show. And here's when he wrote for Jack Paar. He made a hundred and fifty a week and look at him now. And this is his morning show. And his kids. He's divorced.
answer: Look at this. I love these kind of things. Look at the work. I've got this thing about boxes.

question: How much longer are we gonna have to wait?
answer: I don't know. Until he gets back. He should be back pretty soon.

question: Doesn't he have any music or anything? Let's get a little life into this place. It's like a funeral parlor. This is more like it.
answer: Come on, Rita.

question: Come on, yourself. How about a little spin, handsome?
answer: Here?

question: Come on, Rupert. I came up here for a good time. You never could dance, could you?
answer: How would you know?

question: Oh I danced with you a couple of times -- at the Sigma U party.
answer: You were there with Tommy Winston.

question: You didn't ask me.
answer: That's the one time I did ask you and you went with him anyway.

question: Well, I couldn't go with you!
answer: Why not?

question: Be serious, Rupert.
answer: Well, it's all ended happily and that's what counts.

question: I wonder what the rest of this place looks like?
answer: I'm sure it's all very nice.

question: Well, there's only one way to find out. You coming or not?
answer: Rita! Where are you? Come on, Rita. This isn't funny. What are you doing, Rita?

question: I love it! All those millions of women out there dying to change places with me right now.
answer: Come on. We shouldn't be here.

question: Relax, will you. Let me have a little fun, for Christ's sake. Look at this. It's nicer than my whole apartment.
answer: Let's go, Rita.

question: Boy, I really need some sun.
answer: Rita, this is Jerry's ...

question: Lay off, will you, Rupert.
answer: But we have no right ... That wasn't funny, Rita.

question: He did, Jerry. He was very helpful. We had to take an early train. There was nothing else until after one. I brought the material. It's upstairs, in my bags. Where is everybody?
answer: Who?

question: The other guests! We're getting a little hungry, to tell you the truth.
answer: You are.

question: But we don't mind waiting, do we, Rita?
answer: You know, I could have you arrested, both of you.

question: You know you could! And there'd be absolutely no way we could prove we belonged here. I never thought of that.
answer: Well, you should have before you ...

question: Maybe we could work up a routine about that, about a guy who throws all his friends in jail. Let's talk about that.
answer: Let's not.

question: Sure, Jerry. Whatever you ...
answer: Look, if you've got something for me to sign, let's have it and get it over with so I can get back ...

question: That wouldn't be right, Jerry. Not in your own house!
answer: I have a lot of work to get to. How did they get here?

question: We took a taxi, Jerry ... But don't worry about us. You go ahead and do your work and we'll just take a stroll around until lunch is ready.
answer: You're a little thick, aren't you?

question: But what about my material? When are we going to go over it?
answer: Come on, Rupert, the man wants us to go.

question: Tell her she's wrong, Jerry!
answer: Look, Mr. Langford. I didn't know anything about all this. I hardly know this guy. I haven't seen him in years.

question: Rita!
answer: So if there's anything I can do, any way I can make this up to you.

question: She's nothing, Jerry. She's just some girl who works in a bar. Don't let her spoil things.
answer: Come on. Let's go.

question: All I'm asking is fifteen minutes. That's all. Just long enough to listen to my act. Is that asking too much -- fifteen minutes of your day against my whole life?
answer: I'll call the police if I have to. I have my own life, that's all.

question: But what about me, Jerry? What about my life? I made plans -- based on what you said. You can't just turn your back on me.
answer: I'm not telling you again.

question: So this is the way it works when you're big, huh? You just play with people. Is that part of the kick, Jerry? I can see I was all wrong about you. All wrong.
answer: Come on, Rupert.

question: Shut up! You weren't my friend at all, were you? You were just playing some kind of game with me. Well, that's not going to stop me, Jerry. I'm just going to work a little bit harder, that's all, use a little bit more enterprise. And not count on anybody. That's where I made my mistake. I can see that now. Come on, Rita. We're wasting our time.
answer: What did you think was going to happen? You think he'd just ... ? What's the matter with you? You can't just walk into a guy's house! And what about me? What did you ...

question: Shut up, Rita. I'm thinking.
answer: How much longer?!?

question: Do you want him or not?
answer: You sure he's in there?

question: Certain.
answer: My parents are going to be furious! It looks real.

question: That's the whole point. Pay attention.
answer: What if he doesn't come down?

question: He will.
answer: But what if he doesn't?

question: We'll come back tomorrow.
answer: And wait again?

question: Look, you're going to have him all to yourself. What else do you want? Is that him?!?
answer: No.

question: You sure?
answer: Sure I'm sure. That looks too much like him.

question: What do you mean?
answer: When it's him it doesn't look like him.

question: Keep watching.
answer: That's him. What should I do?

question: Wait a second and follow him.
answer: What about here?

question: Too busy. Keep going. Go past him and stop. Just keep walking or I'll kill you right here. I said keep walking. This is a gun in my pocket and I've got nothing to lose.
answer: What do you want?

question: Just keep walking and don't talk to anybody. I'll tell you what to do. Get in!
answer: Look, this is ...

question: I didn't like being so rough out there, Jerry. But I wanted you to know that I meant business. I didn't want anything happening to you over some misunderstanding. Now I know you're wondering what this is all about. Actually you've got nothing to worry about. You just do what I tell you and by, say, midnight, you'll be safe and out of here. Of course if you try anything clever, I'll kill you -- or Marsha will. She knows how to use this too.
answer: You realize what you're saying.

question: Come on, Jerry. This isn't a spur Sit down. Now, you're going to call your office and tell them this
answer: What?

question: Sit down! I said sit!
answer: What's the matter? You heard what he said.

question: All of a sudden, with a gun on him, he wants to make up and be friends. And, once he's out the door, what happens then?
answer: What happens then, Jerry?

question: You get to his office and they jump you, that's what happens, Rupert.
answer: She's right, Jerry.

question: I'm only saying, Mr. Thomas, that we can't allow this to reach the public. When the kidnappers call in, of course you're going to be cooperative. Promise them anything they want. After all, this King character is going to have to show up sooner or later. And once we get our hands on him, he'll tell us where Mr. Langford is. Sure. Let him go on if you have to. It's just a taping. You can always erase him afterwards, can't you? All I'm saying is this
answer: That's fine, Inspector, but let's say he finishes his bit and you've worked him over ...

question: Questioned him, Mr. Thomas.
answer: Okay, questioned him and he still won't talk. We get to eleven thirty and what do we do? Do we air him or what?

question: I would say no.
answer: But they might kill Jerry!

question: Can Randall* sub for Jerry?
answer: His agent's calling us back but it looks good. I only told him Jerry's sick.

question: Well, if worse comes to worse, Canter can always carry it. Let me see your list. Any one of these a writer?
answer: McCabe. The Vanishing Siberian Tiger.

question: Good evening, officer. This is the backstage door I take it?
answer: Your name please?

question: Clarence McCabe, the writer. And this is Mrs. McCabe and her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Solters of Cleveland.
answer: I'm sorry, sir. I don't see you here.

question: I'm on the show tonight, officer.
answer: Well, you're not here.

question: Look, Cathy Long gave me instructions to present myself at a quarter to six. May I see her please?
answer: I'm under strictest orders tonight to admit only authorized personnel.

question: This is absurd. Wait right here.
answer: Stop him!

question: I hope you brought me the right guy this time. Where's Jerry Langford?
answer: Are you on the show?

question: No, Mr. King. That's my assistant, Mr. Giardello.
answer: I want to see someone on the show.

question: Well, you tell us where Mr. Langford is and we'll let you see anyone you want.
answer: Just get me someone from the show.

question: Come on, Mr. King. Let's not fool around. Should we know about any of these people?
answer: That's Orson Bean.

question: I see. Check these out. Now are you going to talk to us, or not?
answer: Sure I'll talk. Just get me someone from the show.

question: Get that Thomas guy in here. We haven't much time, Mr. King. Let's start with your name.
answer: Rupert Pupkin.

question: That's your real name?
answer: Yes sir.

question: You an American?
answer: Yes.

question: Then why do you people do these things?
answer: Are you on the show?

question: Here we, are, Pupkin. I don't know what this is all about, but as soon as you've seen yourself, you're going to talk to us or I promise you, you'll never see daylight again.
answer: I'll need a couple of minutes, Inspector.

question: What?!?
answer: After it's over, I want a couple of minutes. And I'll need ten dollars. Does anyone of you gentlemen have my wallet?

question: Don't push me, Pupkin.
answer: A condemned man's last request, Inspector.

question: Well, I'll tell you right away, the answer is no, Pupkin.
answer: It's not much of a ransom, Inspector ...

question: Look, I'm drawing the line, that's all! No ten dollars and that's it. No -- ten -- dollars!!!! You understand?!?
answer: Sure. Sure, Inspector. No ten dollars ...

question: Okay.
answer: ... and no Jerry Langford. Come on, it's getting late, Inspector.

question: Go ahead. Give him his goddamned ten dollars! Give him twenty! I don't care. Just get him out of here!
answer: Turn on Langford. Seven. Just turn it. Come on.
